Content-Type: text/plain; charset=UTF-8

My guess is that Categories uses Filters and the JUnit3 adapter doesn't
properly handle filters.

It would be nice to get this to work, so if you can write a test that uses
pure junit that reproduces the problem we can look into it.

That being said, I think you should prefer the JUnit4 APIs (the ones under
org.junit) over the JUnit3 APIs.

--047d7bdc18a03d5ee804f70a812e
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

<p dir="ltr">My guess is that Categories uses Filters and the JUnit3 adapter doesn't properly handle filters.</p>
<p dir="ltr">It would be nice to get this to work, so if you can write a test that uses pure junit that reproduces the problem we can look into it.</p>
<p dir="ltr">That being said, I think you should prefer the JUnit4 APIs (the ones under org.junit) over the JUnit3 APIs.<br>
</p>

--047d7bdc18a03d5ee804f70a812e--
